reviewText: Pertinence is the perfect puzzle game for those of you who are patient and willing to think. It starts off very easy, but things start becoming significantly trickier and more challenging as your progress (and also trippier). The game should not be judged by it's simplicity; the graphics may be very simple and minimalistic, but the game itself is rather packed with action. With it's content ranging from fireballs to lasers to absolutely terrifying monsters, Pertinence is free of repetitivity, the deadly sin many, many of it's kind seem to endlessly commit; ultimately and easily making the game one of the standouts of it's genre.
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is really, really great. Requires a lot of patience, as the gauntlets are tough, but I haven't encountered anything that felt impossible.\nIt also looks really, really slick.\nBrand new, and there are some bugs and UI issues, but nothing game-breaking. Well worth it.

reviewText: Psychadelic labyrinth where each room has its own rules of logic to learn and obey. Trippy chiptunes which switch out instruments and movements based on what's going on in the room, including a horrifying red spider with vaccuum powers and dubstep. It's really tough and has some downright unfair runs that remind me of NES games, but I enjoy it in short sessions. The graphics and sound effects add to the minimalist and trippy theme, and I look forward to a soundtrack release.

reviewText: The game is fun, and some of the rooms are very hard, however it feels like some of them either require too much luck, or a crazy spatial and temporal awareness. The game is fun, but very frustraiting, maybe if you belong to the select few who likes to torture your way past i wanna be the guy and games like that you will have the patience to finish some of the rooms.
